mNYBAx-y3.memHandModelNotes:
Species prefers forested and open areas adjacent to permenant water Choose buffer based on high mobility of species.  The average distance from center of the roost area to a foraging location was 109 m on Sapelo Island, GA (Menzel et al. 2003), but this was based on one individual.  NatureServe (2005) classes this bat in the small to medium bat category where they list several other species in the Vespertilionidae family (e.g. Myotis sodalis, lucifugus, & septentrionalis, and Corynorhinus townsendii) as moving between 1.04Km to 4.2 Km, with C. townsendii up 10.5Km) from roosting to foraging ground (this is in the population/occurrence delineation section). So I used a buffer of 2000m b/c in same family of bats. Amy Silvano 20jun05

Change 0m INTO buffer on standing water to 30m to include foraging habitat of "lake edge" referred in habitat notes. MJR 30 January 2008.

references.B94CHO01NAUS: Choate, J. R., J. K. Jones, Jr., and C. Jones. 1994. Handbook of mammals of the south-central states. Louisiana State University Press, Baton Rouge. 304 pp.
references.A99MEN01SEGP: Menzel, J. M., M. A. Menzel, W.M. Ford, J. W. Edwards, S. R. Sheffield, J. C. Kilgo, and M. S. Bunch. 2003. The distribution of bats in South Carolina. Southeastern Naturalist, 2(1), pp. 121-152.
references.B77LAY03SEGP: Layne, J.N.; Stallcup, J.A.; Woolfenden, G.E.; McCauley, M.N.; Worley, D.J.  1977. Fish and Wildlife Inventory of the Seven-County Region Included in the Central Florida Phosphate Industry Area-Wide Environmental Impact Study. Volumes I and II.  Also available as PB-278 457, Price codes: A99 in paper copy, A01 in microfiche. September 1977. Volume I - 643 p, 123 fig, 34 tab, Volume II - 635 p, 164 fig, 7 tab.
references.B69BAR01NAUS: Barbour, R. W., and W. H. Davis. 1969. Bats of America. The University of Kentucky Press, Lexington, Kentucky.
references.B58JEN01SEGP: Jennings, W. L. 1958. The Ecological Ditribution of Bats in Florida. Gainesville, FL: University Press of Florida.
references.A80WEB01SEGP: Webster, W.D., Jones Jr, J.K., and Baker, R.J. 1980. Lasiurus intermedius. Mammalian Species. 132:1-3.
references.B98WHI01NCGP: Whitaker, J.O. Jr. and W.J. Hamilton, Jr. 1998.  Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 583 pp.
references.B12AMM01USGP: Ammerman, L. K., Hice, C. L., and D. J. Schmidly. 2012. Bats of Texas. Texas A & M University Press, College Station, TX. 305 pp.
references.B92KER01SEGP: Kern, W.H. 1992. Northern yellow bat.  Pages 349-356 in Rare and endangered biota of Florida, Vol. I: Mammals (S.R. Humphrey, ed.). Gainesville, Univ. of Florida Press.
references.B85WEB01NAUS: Webster, W. D., J. F. Parnell and W. C. Biggs Jr. 1985. Mammals of the Carolinas, Virginia, and Maryland. The University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, NC.

habitat_description: Within the Southeast, Northern Yellow Bats (Lasurius intermedius) typically inhabit forested areas near permanent water where they frequent both coniferous and deciduous woodlands (Choate et al. 1994 & Webster et al. 1980).  They are strongly associated with Spanish Moss in which they roost and rear their young (Barbour & Davis 1969, Whitaker & Hamilton 1998, Choate et al. 1994 & Webster et al. 1980).  Florida and Georgia roosts are usually in live oaks near permanent water bodies, but they roost in palm trees in southern Texas (Ammerman et al. 2012).  Northern yellow bats are most commonly associated with longleaf pine/turkey oak sandhill and live oak hammock (Jennings 1958 cited in Kern 1992), as well as open flatwoods (Layne et al. 1977). They forage 15-20 feet above the ground over open areas and scattered shrubs or trees, or along forest edge, pastures, airports, golf courses, lake edge, and savannahs (Kern in Humphrey 1992, Ammerman et al. 2012).  Amy Silvano 20jun05, State GAP habitat notes, N. Tarr, 28Aug2013.
